title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with regulatory requirements. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is recognized as an effective advocate for small businesses, ensuring agency responsiveness and compliance with statutory obligations. The independence of the Office is deemed essential for its effectiveness. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is recognized as an effective advocate for small businesses, ensuring agency responsiveness and compliance with statutory obligations. Its independence is crucial for advocating without restrictions from other agencies. The Office requires adequate resources for research to assess regulations' impact on small businesses and provides valuable advice to Congress and executive branch agencies. The purposes of the Office are outlined in Section 3. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration aims to ensure its independence, adequate resources, and reporting requirements to advocate for small businesses, assess regulations' impact, and report to Congress and the President on agency compliance with statutory obligations. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration seeks separate authorization for appropriations, the ability to report to the President and Congress on agency compliance with statutory obligations, and to enhance its role as outlined in chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. OFFICE OF ADVOCACY. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section for the Office of Advocacy. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, includes the Chief Counsel appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy is appointed by the President with Senate approval, without political affiliation, based on fitness for the role. The appointee cannot work for the Small Business Administration for 5 years prior to appointment and can be removed by the President with notification to Congress. Each appropriation request by the Administration must be submitted under section 1108. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy, appointed by the President, must notify Congress 30 days before any removal. Each appropriation request by the Administration must include a separate request for the Office's funding. The Office's primary functions include examining the role of small businesses in the economy and their contributions to various aspects of society and the economy. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy examines the role of small businesses in the economy, their contributions, and assesses Federal subsidy programs for small businesses. It also evaluates government regulations and the impact of the tax structure on small businesses. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy evaluates government regulations on small businesses, tax structure impact, financial market ability to meet credit needs, and financial resource availability for minority assistance. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy evaluates government demands on credit for small businesses, recommends methods for financial resource availability for minority and women-owned enterprises, evaluates efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, and makes recommendations for their development and strengthening. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy evaluates and recommends methods for financial resource availability for minority and women-owned enterprises, makes recommendations for their development and strengthening, and determines criteria for defining small businesses. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy evaluates and recommends methods for financial resource availability for minority and women-owned enterprises, makes recommendations for their development and strengthening, and determines criteria for defining small businesses. It also serves as a focal point for receiving complaints, criticisms, and suggestions regarding small business policies and activities of the Administration and other government departments. Additionally, it makes recommendations and submits reports to relevant committees and the Administrator on issues affecting small businesses. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy serves as a focal point for receiving complaints, criticisms, and suggestions regarding small business policies and activities of the Administration and other government departments. It counsels small businesses on resolving questions and problems with the Federal Government, develops proposals for policy changes, and represents small business interests before other Federal agencies. The Office of the Chief Counsel for Advocacy represents small businesses before Federal agencies, enlists cooperation in disseminating information about government programs, and carries out responsibilities under title 5, United States Code. The Chief Counsel has the authority to appoint staff without regard to civil service laws. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy under title 5, United States Code, has the authority to appoint additional personnel without following civil service laws. Compensation for staff can be set without restrictions, but not exceeding the minimum rate for a GS-15 position. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy has the authority to appoint additional personnel without following civil service laws and set compensation rates not exceeding the minimum rate for a GS-15 position. The Chief Counsel may also procure temporary services and consult with experts in small business investment and venture capital. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy in title 5, United States Code, consults with experts in small business investment, venture capital, and other financial institutions. They also use the services of the National Advisory Council and appoint additional personnel as needed. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy consults with experts in small business investment and appoints advisory boards as necessary. The Administrator provides the Office with office space, equipment, and supplies for its operation. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy consults with experts in small business investment and appoints advisory boards as necessary. The Office is provided with office space, equipment, supplies, and communication facilities for its operation. The Chief Counsel may request information from Federal agencies to carry out their duties. Annual reports are submitted to the President and the Committees on Small Business of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy consults with experts in small business investment and appoints advisory boards as necessary. The Office may request information from Federal agencies. Annual reports on agency compliance with title 5, United States Code are submitted to the President and relevant committees. Additional reports may be prepared and published as deemed appropriate by the Chief Counsel. No report under this section shall be prohibited. The Chief Counsel may prepare and publish reports as deemed appropriate. No report shall be submitted to other government departments before being sent to the President and Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Office to carry out this section. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed. Repeal of Title II of Public Law 94-305 (15 U.S.C. 634a et seq.) and continuation of the incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration in their position. The Senate passed the bill on November 5, 1999. Attest: GARY SISCO, Secretary.
